content.question: Read each question carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. A triangular rod of length <math alttext="L" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and mass <math alttext="M" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> has a nonuniform linear mass density given by the equation <math alttext="lambda equals gamma times x squared" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>λ</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>γ</mi><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="gamma equals the fraction 3 M over L cubed, end fraction" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>γ</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>3</mn><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the distance from point <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>P</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> at the left end of the rod. (a) Using integral calculus, show that the rotational inertia <math alttext="I" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of the rod about an axis perpendicular to the page and through point <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>P</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="three fifths M times L squared" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></mfrac><mi>M</mi><msup><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>.

frqParts.text: Read each question carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. A triangular rod of length <math alttext="L" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and mass <math alttext="M" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> has a nonuniform linear mass density given by the equation <math alttext="lambda equals gamma times x squared" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>λ</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>γ</mi><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="gamma equals the fraction 3 M over L cubed, end fraction" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>γ</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>3</mn><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the distance from point <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>P</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> at the left end of the rod. (a) Using integral calculus, show that the rotational inertia <math alttext="I" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of the rod about an axis perpendicular to the page and through point <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>P</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="three fifths M times L squared" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></mfrac><mi>M</mi><msup><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(b) Determine the horizontal location of the center of mass of the rod relative to point <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>P</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Express your answer in terms of <math alttext="L" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(c) For an axis perpendicular to the page, is the value of the rotational inertia of the rod around point <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>P</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> greater than, less than, or equal to the value of the rotational inertia of the rod around the rod's center of mass? _____ Greater than _____ Less than _____ Equal to Justify your answer.

The rod is released from rest in the position shown, and the rod begins to rotate about a horizontal axis perpendicular to the page and through point <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>P</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. (d) On the axes below, sketch graphs of the magnitude of the net torque <math alttext="tau" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>τ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> on the rod and the angular speed <math alttext="omega" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>ω</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of the rod as functions of time <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> from the time the rod is released until the time its center of mass reaches its lowest point.

(e) As the rod rotates from the horizontal position down through vertical, is the magnitude of the angular acceleration on the rod increasing, decreasing, or not changing?_____ Increasing _____ Decreasing _____ Not changingJustify your answer.

(f) The mass of the rod is <math alttext="3.0 kilograms" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3.0</mn><mtext> kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and the length of the rod is <math alttext="1.0 meter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.0</mn><mtext> m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Calculate the linear speed <math alttext="v" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of point <math alttext="S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>S</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> as the rod swings through the vertical position shown.

skill.text: 1.C: Create qualitative sketches of graphs that represent features of a model or the behavior of a physical system.
